history.content: In my opinion: I believe Sahai said he caters toward the top 0.1% of students -- i.e. the students most similar to him while he was in college. These students are the ones who work hardest. And you can certainly believe they're the ones who don't complain, who exceed in undergraduate and graduate research, and bring prestige to the school. For students at this level, Berkeley remains at least tied with MIT and Stanford.

children.subject: I'm not complaining, I'm just being honest. Berkeley is an amazing school but we're not on par with Stanford and MIT in terms of prestige and funding. That's a fact.
Right but you're basically telling your fellow student body they are not good enough for an amazing Professor like Sahai. Sahai by his own words believes in Berkeley students.

OK fine, ignore the student body part. Stanford and MIT have FAR more resources than Berkeley. I mean, it's not even close. There's no contest. They blow us out of the water. And having more resources has a tangible effect: It means you can research what you want, without having to fight other professors about money.
+1 I find OP's attitude offensive.

Not OP but Stanford and MIT are also not plagued with SJW's like we are. They don't have people blocking Sather Gate or taking over the Campanile after Trump's election. The average person there is more...civilized.

Do you even know what Sahai researches? He's a control and signal processing expert. This is something we are good at, and we have funding for, and requires manpower more than it does financial resources. The brightest students here are as good as the brightest students from MIT and Stanford. Also whoever just called us uncivilized, I don't even know how to respond to something so inflammatory.
Stanford and MIT definitely don't blow us out of the water research-wise... Not sure where you got that idea.
I'm not saying we're not civilized, I'm saying we have more uncivilized people. None of those people that I've seen are in EECS or CS.
Also, not the OP or anon above, but if Berkeley is so good, why aren't we as respected as Stanford or MIT? People are impressed if you go to MIT or Stanford, Berkeley not as much.
There are more than 2 schools in the tech field. Berkeley is literally #3 on most rankings, at most #4 behind CMU. Calm yourself and your ego

To the "uncivilized anon". I'm one of those people you describe as "uncivilized" and I'm CS. Practicing your rights had nothing to do with the quality of education a school offers. Practicing your right and protesting for something that affects the lives of many students does not make you "uncivilized".
You're not uncivilized, the disruptive protesters are.

@anon who complained about SJW's, you realize that the majority of people who go to Stanford are wealthy and white right? I wonder why they're more "civilized".... maybe because they don't have to literally fight for their rights
^agree with above. Y'all are ridiculous, drooling over Stanford
Kunal, post the code for piazza 2.0! @2944.
+1 I've been checked your github every hour for the last few days
+1 Kunal are you trolling us all?
Don't you have anything better to do with your time than complaining about your own school and fellow students. That's not a good way to make friends in a major where friends are compulsory.

By limiting the amount of time he spends with non-top students. Next time faculty advising happens, take a look at his blurb.

This is not referring to lectures, which are much easier to scale than, say, time spent mentoring his students/researchers.

How does Sahai identify top students?

Is tit just based on gpa?

Research experience/potential, academic success (lots of A+'s), incredible work ethic, dedication to academics, success in relevant academic competitions (ACM, Putnam), etc. Having a high GPA is necessary but not sufficient.
How can I join Prof Sahai's circle? I'm not at this level but perhaps I can convince him to accept me.

Student answer: How can Sahai just cater to the top 0.1% of students? I feel like that's extremely unfair to everyone else who also wants a good education here. I think you misinterpreted what Sahai said.

"Student answer: How can Sahai just cater to the top 0.1% of students? I feel like that's extremely unfair to everyone else who also wants a good education here. I think you misinterpreted what Sahai said."

Can someone post the blurb? I've never seen it.

I'll keep this post anonymous since I know I'll get really flak'ed if otherwise, but as a somewhat "outsider" to Berkeley's CS culture right from the beginning, I don't understand why people find the OP's attitude very offensive; Perhaps it was a different time back then (we're talking about 30 years ago, when there wasn't an arms-race), but these days there's some truth due to the rise of more educational resources. 

Due to increasingly high standards, if you take almost any non-URM male from MIT/Stanford, etc. in general they'll have some sort of award (USAMO/IMO, science camps, HS science fairs, etc.).  Internationals are put to even a much higher standard (sometimes requiring a gold medal at XYZ olympiad - I'm not sure how anyone can make the argument against being the top 10 mathematician in a country like China). While they focus on elementary things, these in some way are much harder than anything during undergrad. Especially in mathematical areas, it's not hard to find freshmen already taking out all the graduate courses at MIT to begin with. 


Yes, this is also correlated with opportunities, smart parents, good social networking, and generally a feeling that "it all started from the womb", but I guess that's just life. In terms of resources, a EECS 4.2/5.0 = 3.2/4.0 with just some research automatically qualifies someone for MIT's 5th year M.Eng program, which the vast majority of CS students do to improve their status for grad school, industry, etc. In terms of grading, I've just over time found Berkeley's grading much more unnecessarily hard than it should be - MIT's piazza even had this statement in comparison: 
In terms of GPA, if someone doesn't do well the first term, this already can make them stop trying (and this is a rational behavior - once you have a low gpa, there is barely any incentive to bandage your gpa compared to just trying to excel on other things). MIT has a P/F for freshman fall tailored exactly to protect against this, while we get slapped with a 2.7 average gpa for lower division courses which can easily ruin someone. I never particularly thought that someone accidentally stepping on an academic landmine implied that they were weak at all. MIT has a far bigger "safety net"; even internationally, universities such as Tsinghua in China have a special "CS Yao Class" designed specifically to get their students into top CS grad programs. 

I'm not saying these things to discourage people, but I think I had to post this to inform others just what they're dealing with and what they might be missing out on.

history.content:
Here is a person who got into MIT and Stanford for both undergrad and grad school, and got tenure at these schools. Yet he turned them down for Berkeley. I still don't get why he did that. What did he see in this school? We have a smaller endowment, a lot more students, less funding for research, less prestige, lower salaries for Professors....yet he still chose us. Why? 

Professor Sahai has said Berkeley students are hard working, they don't complain. Problem is, we do complain (A LOT) as seen on UCBMFET. Also, MIT and Stanford undergrads are hardworking as well.

Looking for some genuine life advice from one of Berkeley's finest Professors.
history.subject: Why did Prof. Sahai choose Berkeley?
